CITY OF COCOA
RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM RE-SUBMITTAL
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY INTRODUCTION 68.155                                                                        
The City of Cocoa Utilities Department operates the City of Cocoa Claude H. Dyal (Dyal) Water Treatment Plant at 28400 E. SR 520, Christmas, Orange County, Florida.  This plant is one of two water plants operated by the City.  Only the Dyal water plant has quantities of a regulated hazardous chemical, chlorine, above the EPA threshold.  The separate Wewahootee water treatment plant has eliminated chlorine from its operation.  The City has a unified Risk Management Program which applies to each plant.  Only the Dyal Water Treatment Plant operations and policies are presented in this Plan.

1.1.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES     (A)
The City of Cocoa Water Treatment Plant accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach that integrates technologies, procedures and management practices.  The plant prevention program complies with all applicable procedures of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Risk Management Program (RMP) 40 CFR-68 Prevention Program under the Clean Air Act Amendments of 1990.

1.2.    MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS (A) (1)
The City of Cocoa has a management system in place which is led by the City Manager.  The City Utilities Director oversees the implementation and on-going use of the RMP elements.  This program, along with other City-wide and plant-specific policies, eliminates and/or reduces the likelihood of a hazardous chemical release at the plant.  An organizational chart defining the lines of authority and responsible staff is included in the plants RMP Process Safety Information.

1.3.    PREVENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 3 (A) (2)
The City of Cocoa maintains policies, procedures and systems as part of their prevention program.  These are applied to each treatment plant and specifically the Dyal Water Treatment Plant.  The program add

resses each of the EPA Program Level 3-listed 12 elements, plus RMP elements needed to implement the program, and the like elements in place in the plantsA? OSHA PSM program which the City is exempt from compliance with.  These are maintained by the Water Treatment Plant Document Management System (DMS).

1.4.    STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED AT CITY OF COCOA, FLORIDA SITE (B)  
The City of Cocoa Water Treatment Plant employs 42 full-time and one part time employee engaged in water treatment plant and field operations.  Chlorine is used as part of the treatment process.

1.5.    SITE DESCRIPTION (B) (1)    
The site is owned and operated by The City of Cocoa and managed by its Utilities Department.  The site is located at 28400 E. SR 520, Christmas, Orange County, Florida.   The 88 acre site is located in an area boarded by SR 520 on the east, South Taylor Creek Rd on the west.
The Plant includes a separate chlorine storage building and adjacent control room plus injection feed distribution system that is contained in a separate process room as well as at various injector pointsA? cabinets.
The boundaries of the chlorine system subject to the RMP regulation include the Bulk Chlorine Storage Room, Feed Control room, associated vent makeup, exhaust systems, chlorine scrubber and chlorine injection cabinets at various injection points.  These are detailed in the Process and Instrument Drawings (P&ID) which are part of the plant Process Safety Information (PSI).  All drawings are maintained in the plants RMP Process Safety Information.
1.5.1.    REGULATED SUBSTANCE (b) (2)
Chlorine is the only regulated substance on site which exceeds the EPA 40 CFR-68 rule threshold quantity of 2500 pounds.  The City of Cocoa chlorine process was installed as part of the process of purifying water for public consumption.  It operates under permit from the State of Florida Department of Environmental Protection (FL DEP).  The chlorine is received, stored and distributed to water

treatment process control systems. 
Chlorine is an EPA and OSHA-listed toxic chemical.  It is an irritant and it is corrosive.  Chlorine is a halogen with the formula Cl2.  It is a chlorinating or oxidizing agent that is not flammable.  It has a 1 ppm OSHA ceiling Permissible Exposure Limit (PEL) and a NFPA health rating of 4, severe; with immediate and delayed health hazards.  Chlorine is not a carcinogen.
The maximum threshold quantity stored on site is 24 one ton containers.  This equals 48,000 pounds.

2.    HAZARD ASSESSMENT
A hazard assessment was performed to determine the effects a release would have on the public. For chlorine, the distance to a set endpoint concentration of the gas would travel must be determined.  In addition, an estimate of the population that could be affected by a release of chlorine was determined, and sensitive receptors such as hospitals, schools, and nursing homes were identified. The hazard assessment considers two release scenarios-a "worst case" and an "alternative case" and also compiles the five-year accident history for the WTP chlorine system.
Two offsite consequence analyses were conducted which include two chlorine release scenarios.  The first is a A?worst case releaseA?.  The second is a more probable A?alternative release scenarioA?.  The first scenario is defined by EPA, which states that A?the operator shall assume that the maximum quantity in the largest vessel is released as a gas over 10 minutesA? due to an unspecified failure.  The alternative scenario is defined as A?more likely to occur than the worst-case scenarioA?.
Atmospheric dispersion modeling was performed to determine the distance traveled by the chlorine released before its concentration decreases to the A?toxic endpoint.A?  The EPA specified endpoint for chlorine is 0.0087 mg/l which equals 3 ppm. The 3 ppm endpoint is the Emergency Response Planning Guideline Level 2 (ERPG-2).  This is defined by the American Industrial Hygiene Association (AIHA) as the

A?maximum airborne concentration below which it is believed that nearly all individuals could be exposed for up to one hour without experiencing or developing irreversible or other serious health effects or symptoms which could impair an individualA?s ability to take protective action.A?  The residential population within a circle with a radius corresponding to the toxic endpoint distance was defined, A?to estimate the population potentially affected.A?

2.1.    WORST CASE   (C) (1)
Atmospheric dispersion modeling for the worst case scenario was performed using the EPA assumptions and EPAA?s RMP Comp Program.  Results demonstrate a distance to the toxic endpoint of 1.3 miles containing 5.3 square miles of area assuming an urban topography without an enclosure.  The residential population that could potentially be affected by the release is ___ individual based on the U. S. Census 2000 demographic data.  There is one residence and industry included in that release area.  However, there are ___ residences within the radius. The population data is maintained in the Plant's PSI.

2.2.    ALTERNATIVE CASE   (C) (2)
The alternative release scenario involves the failure of the regulator of the pressure system or the wip on pipes/valves connected to one of the one-ton containers.  This failure was defined during the recent Process Hazards Analysis.  This failure is equal to creating a 0.03 square inch hole in the wip tube, a pipe, or even the container itself.  Modeling using the EPA/RMP Comp and EPAA?s water guidance demonstrated the rate of chlorine release is 200.0 lb. /minutes for a period of 60 minutes releasing a total of 2,000 pounds of chlorine.  The toxic endpoint distances determined is 0.30 miles and is in the process safety information.  The residential population that would be impacted by this release is ____ and is recorded in the process safety information.  Receptors in this area were identified as ___ adjacent to the plant.  The demographic data is kept in the P

lant's PSI.

3.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM (D)
The City of Cocoa accidental release prevention program is based on OSHAA?s PSM program and EPAA?s RMP Level 3 prevention program.  The PSM program has been in place and effectively used for many years.  It is part of the plants operating culture.  There are two parts to the program.  The first is the general overall water division wide program and the Water Treatment Plant site-specific program.  The second is the chlorine-specific actions within the site program.  This is coordinated with the Orange County Fire/Rescue Department (including the Haz Mat Team) and the Regional LEPC.

3.1.    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM   (D) (1)
Plant-wide, many elements of the prevention program are used for all operations.  An overview of the generally written programs is listed below:
The City of Cocoa has detailed process safety information on each of its operations. 
The document maintenance system is integral to the management of change for all operations on site control.  
Training is the backbone of employee knowledge, job operations and is ongoing in each area.  Employee training in operations and maintenance emphasizes awareness of the hazardous and toxic properties of all chemicals used. Refresher training is conducted annually.
Maintenance and preventive maintenance are used for all operations making mechanical integrity a part of each piece of equipment. 
Incident investigations of accidents and near-miss incidents ensure we learn from each event as well as correct the causes of the incident. 
Employees participate in all aspects of the plant as listed below under emergency response. 
Safe work practices are used throughout the facility including:  1) Hot Work Permits, 2) Lock Out Tag Out Permits, 3) Vessel Entry Permits, 4) Site Security, and 5) Breaking Into Chemical Lines. 
Contractors must meet The City of CocoaA?s high safety and technical standards as part of selection and ongoing evaluations.

Plus, City of Cocoa demands training of contractors to our standards. 

3.2.    CHLORINE SPECIFIC RESPONSE PROGRAM (D) (2)
3.2.1.    Chlorine-Specific Operating Safety Information
Chemical-specific prevention features of the plant include: the policies and procedures listed above and those of the chlorine specific program.  These include:
3.2.2.    Specific procedures for the management of the chlorine process. 
Completion of a Pre-startup Safety Review prior to startup of the modified chlorine system.   
Specific emergency response procedures for chlorine releases as outlined below under both operating procedures and in the emergency response procedures. See the Emergency Response Program book. 
Specific training in the properties, hazards, handling requirements, and leak repair for chlorine is conducted annually. 
Finally, the details of both facility and equipment design are key to the safe operations of the chlorine system.
3.2.3.    Facility Design
The chlorine storage area is housed in a closed building.  Its doors are closed and locked requiring an entry key. The plant and support equipment of the chlorine storage building and adjacent control room meet and exceed design codes standards and good engineering practices.  The storage and control building room is equipped with forced ventilation system.  There is a chlorine area monitor inside the storage building.  If chlorine is detected, the monitor alarms and shuts down the forced air ventilation system.  It also starts the building chlorine vent fume scrubber.  The scrubber is capable of neutralizing over 2000 pounds of chlorine.  The control room also has a chlorine monitor.  Both monitors alarm in their local area as well as in the water plant control room. 
3.2.4.    Equipment Design
There are two types of chlorine pipe systems, high pressure and low (vacuum) pressure.  The high pressure chlorine piping system is made of chlorine compatible steel pipes, copper tubes or equipment.  These materials are steel, copper or

chlorine compatible non-metallic compound (not corroded by chlorine) rated to 500 psig.  The maximum pressure of the chlorine in the high pressure system is only 150 psig giving a 3 to 1 safety factor.  There are two sets of six ton containers on each high pressure line.  Each leads to an automatic switch over a vacuum pressure regulator. One bank is in service and the other is on standby. 
The low pressure system operates under a vacuum pressure of 13 inches of mercury.  There is a pressure relief valve which vents if the pressure in the line reaches above atmospheric pressure.  All the pipe, tubes, and equipment are also chlorine compatible.  The system is designed to 150 psig or complete vacuum giving it a large safety factor over the typical vacuum or positive pressure in it.  There is a chlorine monitor which detects the presence of chlorine in the ton storage area and a second monitor in the chlorine control room. 

4.    FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY (E)
The plant has been chlorine reportable and release free since 1992 to the present, 17 years.

5.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM (F)
Emergency response procedures are contained both the Plant Emergency Response Policy that is coordinated with the Orange County Contingency Plan (Emergency Response Plan).  The plan includes an emergency response A?decision treeA? and a notification plan.  The Plant also has site specific emergency actions defined in the plants operating procedures.  Emergency response drills are conducted annually by the operating department.  Emergency operation and response procedures are also reviewed annually.
The emergency response program (contingency plan) is coordinated (reviewed by) with the water plant Safety Committee.  The Water Plant coordinates with local Orange County Emergency Response Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Orange County HazMat Team.  All are located in Orange County, Florida.  Copies of the program are given to key local agencies including: fire, medical, rescue, management, a

nd police departments.  Besides the specific emergency response program, key elements of the prevention programs are incorporated in the operating culture of the City water plant.
The Contingency Plan procedures detail the actions and responses to chlorine spills (releases).  The plan includes training of all chlorine-area operators. The primary response team includes the Orange County Fire and Rescue, and county Haz Mat Teams.  All of these respond to any severe chlorine leak situation.  Actions include catastrophic, severe, and moderate leaks.  A Chlorine A?BA? Leak Repair Kit is maintained at the chlorine storage area to aid in stopping leaks.  Public notification is facilitated through the County Police and SheriffA?s Office, which has an automated emergency dialing message system for public notification.

6.    PERSONNEL (F) (1)
Personnel are the key resource of the City of CocoaA?s prevention program.  City employees make up the operators and emergency operations first responders.  The City of Cocoa fosters a high level of involvement in every aspect of the chlorine system operations including participation in:
A?    PSM/RMP safety teams, 
A?    Development of the operation procedures, 
A?    Hazard evaluations and 
A?    On-going training of the operators and other involved staff.
A?    Process Hazards Analysis (PHA)

7.    CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY (G)
Changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were identified in the internal safety HazOp, tour, and audit of the RMP program to meet requirements of the Risk Management Prevention Program.  These recommended actions have now been evaluated and implemented as required.  An Audit was conducted to review the PSM and RMP program.  The key safety action items were completed.  See the A?UpdateA? Section 6 of the Audit Report.  The City of Cocoa continually reviews implemented operating procedures for potential safety improvements for all of its operations.  Currently, the City of Cocoa Dyal plant management team and process safety t

eam are reviewing potential upgrades to the existing design of the chlorine operations to make the system even safer to prevent a release and minimize consequences in the event of a release of chlorine.
The City of Cocoa Water Treatment Plant recently compiled the EPA required Vulnerability Assessment.  Recommendations from the VA Report improve site security and safety over all including that of the chlorine system.
